Coastal and Marine Resources Management in the

In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The Coral Triangle’s marine and coastal resources are at risk from continued threats 
from climate change-induced processes, such as wave actions and storm surges, as well as 
from human activities, including reef dynamiting and cyanide poisoning for higher fish yields, 
sand mining for construction, reef breaking for coral harvesting, and pollution from land-based 
sources.  Consequently,  the  Coral  Triangle  Initiative  on  Coral  Reefs,  Fisheries,  and  Food 
Security (CTI) 1 was launched in 2007 as a six-country regional cooperation program to protect 
the  Coral  Triangle’s  economic  and  environmental  assets.  Since  its  launch,  the  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) has been fully involved in efforts to provide technical and financial 
support to the CTI, with an assistance package valued at $294.4 million, consisting of $97.6 
million (33.2%) in grants and $196.8 million (66.8%) in loans. 
 
2.  These threats are key to the protection and conservation of the Coral Triangle and will 
be addressed by the proposed technical assistance (TA)2 by supporting the implementation of 
the national plans of action of the CTI.3  The TA, with cofinancing from the Global Environment 
Facility, aims to enhance coastal and marine resources management by providing technical and 
operational support for institutional strengthening; application of the ecosystems approach to 
fishery management; development of alternative livelihoods for poor coastal communities; and 
coordination of stakeholders in Indonesia, Malaysia, and the Philippines (which are also known 
as Coral Triangle Southeast Asia or CT3). The governments of the CT3 were consulted and 
agreed with the TA impact, output, outcomes, implementation arrangements, cost and financing 
arrangements, and terms of reference for consultants. This TA is one of three regional TA 
projects comprising ADB’s core support to the CTI.4 The design and monitoring framework is in 
Appendix 1 and a detailed description of the project activities is in Supplementary Appendix A. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  Covering  nearly  5.7  million  square  kilometers  of  ocean  around  six  countries  (i.e., 
Indonesia, Malaysia, Papua New Guinea, the Philippines, Solomon Islands, and Timor-Leste, 
known as the CT6), the Coral Triangle is often referred to as the “Amazon of the Seas.” It 
contains 76% of all known coral species and 53% of the world’s coral reefs; about 3,000 species 
of reef fish, including 40% of all known coral reef fish species; and the greatest extent of 
mangroves in the world. It also serves as the spawning and juvenile growth areas for the world’s 
largest and most valuable tuna fishery and provides income and food security to more than 120 
million  people,  particularly  the  area’s  coastal  communities.  Its  fishery  exports  and  coastal 
tourism revenues are reported to provide a combined annual foreign exchange income of about 
$6.0 billion. 
 
 
                                                 
1  The overarching commitments to action of the CTI are (i) designating and managing priority seascapes, (ii) 
applying the ecosystem approach to the management of fisheries and other marine resources, (iii) establishing and 
managing  marine  protected  areas,  (iv)  achieving  climate  change  adaptation  measures,  and  (v)  improving 
threatened species statuses. 
2  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 4 November 2010. 
3  The national  plans of action focus on seascape management, ecosystem approach to fishery and marine 
resources management, effective marine protected area management, coastal and marine resources management 
for climate change adaptation, and endangered species management. 
4  The other two TA projects are (i) ADB. 2009. Technical Assistance to the Coral Triangle for Regional Cooperation 
on Knowledge Management, Policy, and Institutional Support to the CTI. Manila (TA 7307-REG); and (ii) ADB. 
2010. Technical Assistance for Strengthening Coastal and Marine Resources Management in the Coral Triangle of 
the Pacific. Manila (TA 7753-REG).

2   
4.  Many fisher families in the CT3 live in subsistence conditions, their livelihoods becoming 
further hampered by the destruction of coral reefs and collapse of marine resources. Problems 
of credit repayment, increasing debt, and low prices from middlepeople and/or traders have 
often led these fishers to destructive, illegal fishing methods (e.g., dynamiting) in an attempt to 
increase their catches. About 90% of the fish in the CT3 is caught by fishers dependent on coral 
reefs for a living, and reef degradation, which has resulted in a drop in fish production, is 
severely  affecting  the  incomes  and  living conditions  of coastal communities.  For  example, 
income losses from 21,000 square kilometers of coral reef areas in the Philippines alone had 
been estimated at $1.2 billion over 20 years.5 
 
5.  In addition to poverty and resource degradation issues, the CT3 coastal and marine 
resources sectors suffer from policy, legal, and institutional constraints. While environmental 
and resource management policies and legislation are in place, they are not implemented to the 
fullest extent due to the lack of budgetary allocations and interagency rivalries. Moreover, while 
the CT3 have decentralized systems of coastal and marine resources management, the lack of 
institutional capacity and preparedness of many local governments for the required tasks has 
hampered  ongoing  and  planned  initiatives  and  exacerbated  the  problems  of  resource 
degradation and poverty prevalence.  
 
6.  At the subnational levels, capacity development is needed by the relevant government 
agencies to equip them for their responsibilities in coastal and marine resources management, 
particularly  local  resources  planning,  formulation  of  integrated  coastal  zone  management 
policies  and  implementing  guidelines  within  the  framework  of  national  policies,  and 
comanagement with local communities. At the national level, support must be continued for 
sector planning and policy formulation, intersector coordination and networking, as well as 
knowledge  management  to  support  resources  management  decisions.  Finally,  there  is  an 
urgent need to raise income levels and living standards among the coastal communities so that 
they can exercise effective stewardship over coastal resources, particularly coral reefs and 
associated ecosystems. For these communities, alternative livelihood activities must also be 
developed, with a focus on investment opportunities, to improve their income-earning potential.  
 
III.  THE PROPOSED TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
7.  The  proposed  TA  will  result  in  the  increased  resilience  of  coastal  and  marine 
ecosystems and human communities in the CT3. The outcome will be improved management of 
coastal  and  marine  resources  established  in  the  Sulu–Sulawesi  Marine  Ecoregion  Priority 
Seascape within the Coral Triangle.6 The TA will support the introduction of more effective 
management of coastal and marine resources, especially those associated with coral reef 
ecosystems, to build their resilience in a period of increased threats arising from climate change 
and  human-induced  impacts,  thereby  maintaining  ecosystem  integrity  and  productivity  and 
ensuring the improved socioeconomic status of coastal communities. 
 
                                                 
5  H. Cesar, L. Burke. and L. Pet-Soede. 2003. The Economics of Worldwide Coral Reef Degradation. Amhem, 
Netherlands: Cesar Environmental Economics Consulting. 
6  The Sulu–Sulawesi Marine Ecoregion also covers the Greater Sulu–Sulawesi Corridor that was identified for 
accelerated  infrastructure  improvement  under  the  Brunei  Darussalam–Indonesia–Malaysia–Philippines  East 
ASEAN Growth Area economic program facilitated by ADB. The ecoregion was also declared a priority seascape 
for CTI implementation during the 4th CTI Senior Officials’ Meeting held in Kota Kinabalu, Sabah, Malaysia in 
October 2009.

3
8.  The  TA7 complements  ongoing  and  planned  efforts  in  the  Coral  Triangle  of  ADB’s 
Southeast  Asia  Department,8 as  well  as  its  development  partners,  such  as  the  Global 
Environment  Facility,  United  States  Agency  for  International  Development,9 and  Australian 
Agency for International Development, which all aim to support the CT6 in the conservation and 
management of coral reefs and associated habitats for food security and poverty reduction. The 
TA also supports ADB’s Strategy 2020, which recognizes the urgent need to promote locally 
and globally environmentally sustainable economic growth, invest in sound environmental and 
natural  resources  management,  and  further  strengthen  regional  initiatives  for  adapting  to 
climate  change.10 It  is  likewise  aligned  with  ADB’s  Regional  Cooperation  and  Integration 
Strategy, the fourth pillar of which is cooperation in regional public goods.11 The TA supports the 
country partnership strategy of the respective CT3 countries. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
9.  The  TA  impact  and  outcome  will  be  attained  through  three  outputs:  (i)  policy  and 
institutional frameworks for sustainable coastal and marine ecosystem management improved, 
(ii) ecosystem-based approach to coastal and marine resources management pilot tested, and 
(iii) effective project management established by ADB and the CT3 governments. 
 
10.  Output 1: Policy and institutional frameworks for sustainable coastal and marine 
resources management improved. The TA will support the CT3 governments in establishing 
an enabling environment for sustainable coastal and marine resources management through (i) 
improving  policy  and  legal  frameworks,  and  monitoring  their  enforcement;  (ii)  building 
institutional capacity of national, subnational, and local government agencies in planning and 
implementation of resources management plans, programs, and projects in marine conservation 
areas, reserves, and production seascapes; (iii) strengthening staff capability to understand the 
impacts  of  climate  change,  need  for  climate  change  adaptation,  and  identification  and 
implementation of technically appropriate and effective adaptation measures; (iv) promoting 
sustainable  financing  of  resources  management  and  adaptation  measures;  (v)  mentoring 
government staff in the application of decision support tools in knowledge management and the 
production of tangible knowledge products (e.g., technical reports, guidelines, manuals, policy 
briefs,  news  articles,  and  other  public  awareness  materials);  and  (vi)  conducting  public 
awareness campaigns to improve stakeholders’ appreciation of the need for coastal and marine 
resources management as a tool for improving the resilience of ecosystems and communities to 
climate change and other threats. 
 
                                                 
7  This TA is one of three regional TA projects comprising ADB’s core support to the CTI that are geared to assist the 
CT6 in developing strategies and activities to implement their respective national plans of action for the CTI and 
facilitate  cooperation  on  regional  issues.  The  Technical  Assistance  for  Strengthening  Coastal  and  Marine 
Resources Management in the Coral Triangle of the Pacific (TA 7753-REG) will support actions to help ensure 
food security for the population in Pacific CTI countries (Papua New Guinea, Solomon Islands, and Timor-Leste), 
Fiji Islands, and Vanuatu, resulting from the increased resilience of coastal and marine ecosystems. The Technical 
Assistance to the Coral Triangle for Regional Cooperation on Knowledge Management, Policy, and Institutional 
Support to the CTI (TA 7307-REG) will link the Southeast Asian and Pacific CTI activities of ADB and facilitate CTI-
wide information exchange and learning—including program management and coordination support. 
8  ADB. 2008. Technical Assistance for Strengthening Sound Environmental Management in the Brunei Darussalam–
Indonesia–Malaysia–Philippines East ASEAN Growth Area. Manila (TA 6446-REG). 
9  The Government of the United States has a financing commitment of $42.15 million for the CTI in Southeast Asia 
and the Pacific, of which $16.00 million (or 32% of the total) is intended for Indonesia, Malaysia, and the 
Philippines. 
10  ADB. 2008. Strategy 2020: The Long-Term Strategic Framework of the Asian Development Bank, 2008–2020. 
Manila. 
11  ADB. 2006. Regional Cooperation and Integration Strategy. Manila.

4   
 
11.  Output  2:  Ecosystem-based  approach  to  coastal  and  marine  resources 
management pilot-tested. This output directly addresses illegal, unreported, and unregulated 
fishing; overfishing; destruction of natural habitats; and other constraints to sustainable fishery 
management and economic development in coastal communities. A holistic, comprehensive, 
and integrated ecosystem-based approach to coastal and marine resources management will 
be demonstrated at the national and regional levels through the (i) effective management of 
marine  protected  areas;  (ii)  pilot  implementation  of  a  fishery  monitoring,  control,  and 
surveillance system in the Sulu–Sulawesi Marine Ecoregion Priority Seascape; (iii) pilot testing 
of ridge-to-reef management of a coastal zone with large-scale agricultural plantations and 
marine industries; and (iv) development and pilot testing of sustainable livelihood activities as a 
means of reducing fishing pressure on resources and improving the socioeconomic conditions 
of coastal communities in Sabah, Malaysia. Opportunities for public–private partnerships in the 
development  of  business  and  management  plans  for  marine  protected  areas,  sustainable 
financing  schemes,  and  climate  change  adaptation  interventions  and/or  measures  will  be 
identified and pursued, and women will be encouraged and supported in livelihood and/or 
enterprise development in the ecoregion. 
 
12.  Output  3:  Effective  project  management  established  by  ADB  and  the  CT3 
governments. A project management system will be set up, consisting of (i) a TA coordination 
unit within ADB’s Southeast Asia Environment, Natural Resources and Agriculture Division 
(SEER); (ii) a regional project management office; and (iii) national project coordination offices 
(NPCOs)  in  each  CT3.  A  project  performance  management  system  will  be  designed  and 
installed in the ADB TA coordination unit and NPCOs, which will include agreed performance 
indicators, targets, and data and/or information sources as defined in the design and monitoring 
framework. An international project coordinator and monitoring and evaluation specialist and a 
project management consultant will be engaged by ADB to support the countries in project 
planning and implementation, and to liaise with ADB and the CTI secretariat. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
13.  The TA is estimated to cost $15.2 million equivalent, of which (i) $11.2 million will be 
financed on a grant basis by the Global Environment Facility and administered by ADB, and (ii) 
$1.0 million will financed on a grant basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF–
other sources). The governments of the CT3 will each contribute $1.0 million equivalent through 
in-kind support and related costs, for a total of $3.0 million equivalent. The cost estimates and 
financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
14.  Executing and implementing agencies. ADB, through SEER, will be the executing 
agency, while the implementing agencies will be CTI focal agencies in the CT3: (i) Ministry of 
Marine Affairs and Fisheries, Indonesia; (ii) National Oceanography Directorate of the Ministry 
of Science, Technology and Innovation, Malaysia; and (iii) Department of Environment and 
Natural Resources, Philippines. The TA will be implemented over a 4-year period with a target 
commencement date of 1 July 2011 and an end date of 30 June 2015. 
 
15.  Project management. A TA coordination unit will be set up within SEER under an 
international project coordinator, to be recruited directly by ADB, who will oversee day-to-day TA 
implementation on behalf of ADB. The TA coordination unit will liaise with other relevant ADB 
units  and/or  offices,  particularly  the  Pacific  Department  and  the  Regional  and  Sustainable

5
Development Department. At the national level, an NPCO will be set up in each implementing 
agency to oversee and coordinate the implementation of TA activities in the field. The NPCOs 
will  be  responsible  for  (i)  preparing  work  plans;  (ii)  setting  up  a  project  performance 
management system for monitoring the work program under the project outputs, linking the 
national  coordination  committees  to  the  CTI  monitoring  and  evaluation  system  at  the  CTI 
secretariat, and preparing local progress and monitoring reports; and (iii) coordinating in-country 
activities, and liaising with the national coordination committees and the Global Environment 
Facility focal points. A detailed description of the TA implementation arrangements, including 
the project organization structure and funds flow, is in Supplementary Appendix B. 
 
16.  Consulting services. The TA will require 64 person-months of international and 640 
person-months of national consulting services. The outline terms of reference are in Appendix 3, 
and  further  details  are  provided  in  Supplementary  Appendix  C.  ADB  will  engage  the 
international project coordinator and monitoring and evaluation specialist on an individual basis 
to serve for 24 person-months. A project management consultant (i.e., firm) will be recruited to 
supply 34 person-months of international and 630 person-months of national consulting services 
to support in-country project management and implementation. The firm will also be responsible 
for the management and administration of various training programs, workshops, conferences, 
and  surveys,  including  subcontracting  of  various  service  providers  such  as  academic  and 
training institutions, local nongovernment organizations, and community-based organizations. 
 
17.  In addition, the firm will establish a regional project management office that will be 
responsible for overall TA management at the regional level and for coordination between the 
NPCOs and the CTI secretariat, as well as between the NPCOs and the TA coordination unit. 
The office will establish links with other projects implemented in the Sulu–Sulawesi Marine 
Ecoregion Priority Seascape and under the CTI program framework of the Global Environment 
Facility.  It  will  also  prepare  regular  progress  reports  for  submission  to  the  CTI  national 
coordination committees and senior officials' meetings. It will be supervised by an international 
team leader and project management specialist, assisted by three deputy team leaders and 
institutional  development  specialists  (one  for  each  country),  who  will  head  the  respective 
NPCOs and be responsible for project management at the national level. Another international 
firm will be engaged by ADB to prepare a study on scaling up investment program for coastal 
resources management in Indonesia. Six person-months of international consultants and 10 
person-months of national consultants are required for this study. 
 
18.  Firms will be selected using quality- and cost-based selection method (90:10) following 
ADB’s  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of  Consultants  (2010,  as  amended  from  time  to  time). 
Disbursements will be done in accordance with ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement 
Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S RECOMMENDATION AND DECISION 
 
19.  The President recommends that the Board approve ADB administering a portion of 
technical  assistance  not  exceeding  the  equivalent  of  $11,218,180  for  Coastal  and  Marine 
Resources Management in the Coral Triangle—Southeast Asia, to be financed on a grant basis 
by the Global Environment Facility. If the Board approves ADB administering the technical 
assistance, the President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, will approve ADB 
providing the balance of the technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,000,000 on 
a grant basis for the Coastal and Marine Resources Management in the Coral Triangle—
Southeast Asia.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Introduction 
 
1.  This appendix provides a summary of the consulting services required during technical 
assistance (TA) implementation and the type of technical services and/or specialist inputs to be 
provided under three contract packages: (i) one international project coordinator and monitoring 
and evaluation specialist to be hired directly by the Asian Development Bank (ADB), 24 person-
months; (ii) one international project management consultant (i.e., firm) that will provide 34 
person-months of international consultants and 630 person-months of national consultants; and 
(iii) another international firm to hired directly by ADB to prepare a study on scaling up the 
investment program for coastal and marine resources management in Indonesia. Six person-
months of international consultants and 10 person-months of national consultants are required 
for this study. The international consultancy firms will be recruited through quality- and cost-
based selection method (90:10).1 These consultants will be engaged following ADB’s Guidelines 
on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). The outline terms of reference 
are given below, and the organization of the consulting services and detailed terms of reference 
are in Supplementary Appendix C. 
 
B.  Project Coordinator and Monitoring and Evaluation Specialist (Individual) 
(international, 24 person-months) 
 
2.  An international project coordinator will be engaged directly by ADB to manage the 
operations of the TA coordination unit at ADB, design and establish the project performance 
management  system,  and  monitor  the  activities  of  the  participating  countries  during  TA 
implementation. The coordinator will (i) liaise closely with the project management consultant to 
ensure that work planning, financial management, and project reporting are consistently applied 
using an agreed format and agreed timelines; (ii) review work plans and budgets; (iii) review 
procurement documentation; and (iv) report on project progress to ADB. 
 
C.  Project  Management  Consultant  (international,  34  person-months;  national,  630 
person-months) 
 
3.  An  international  consulting  firm  will  be  engaged  by  ADB  to  serve  as  the  project 
management  consultant  with  responsibility  for  the  provision  of  day-to-day  technical  and 
administrative support to the national project coordination offices in the participating countries 
during  project  implementation,  including  (i)  detailed  work  planning,  (ii)  coordinating  the 
implementation of demonstration or pilot projects, (iii) procurement of goods and services, (iv) 
financial management, and (v) documentation and reporting. The consulting firm will provide the 
services of the following consultants: (i) an international team leader and project management 
specialist; (ii) three deputy team leaders to coordinate project inputs and ensure consolidation of 
country reports and documents (including country work plans, progress and financial reports, 
and statements of expenses) and reporting these to the project coordinator; (iii) coastal and 
marine  resources  management  policy  specialist  and  knowledge  management  specialist  to 
support the Coral Triangle Initiative on Coral Reefs, Fisheries, and Food Security secretariat; 
and  (iv)  short-term  technical  specialists,  both  international  and  national,  who  will  provide 
specialized inputs in the conduct of studies and various technical analyses, depending on the 
specific requirements of the countries (Table A3). 
                                                 
1  Given the need to ensure that a firm with the technical skills and project management experience is recruited by 
ADB, a heavier weight will be given to the technical merits of the proposals. Hence, the project management
